sub_topic: Identifying the automorphism group of a graph.
message_1:
Consider the graph G shown below:

```
      A
      |
  D---B---C
```

Find the automorphism group of G, that is, the group of all permutations of its vertices that preserve its edge structure.
message_2:
An automorphism of a graph is a permutation of its vertices that preserves adjacency. In other words, an automorphism maps edges to edges and non-edges to non-edges. The automorphism group of a graph is the set of all its automorphisms, with the group operation being the composition of permutations.

For the given graph G, we can identify the following automorphisms:

1. The identity automorphism, which maps each vertex to itself:
   A -> A, B -> B, C -> C, D -> D

2. The automorphism that swaps vertices C and D:
   A -> A, B -> B, C -> D, D -> C

These are the only two automorphisms that preserve the edge structure of G. To see why, note that vertex A has degree 1, while the other vertices have degree 2. Therefore, any automorphism must map A to itself, as it is the only vertex with degree 1. Similarly, B must be mapped to itself, as it is the only vertex adjacent to A. This leaves only two possibilities for the images of C and D: either they are mapped to themselves (the identity automorphism) or they are swapped (the second automorphism).

Thus, the automorphism group of G is the group with two elements: {identity, (C D)}, where (C D) denotes the permutation that swaps C and D. This group is isomorphic to the cyclic group of order 2, denoted as Z_2 or C_2.
